thread.title: Gold prices fall as US growth eyed
thread.title_full: Gold prices fall as US growth eyed | Business Spectator

author: Dow Jones newswires
title: Gold prices fall as US growth eyed
text:
Gold prices were lower on the London spot market on Wednesday, after positive data out of the US reminded the market that a rise in US interest rates by the Federal Reserve is likely this year.
Spot gold was down 0.3 per cent at $US1,123.61 a troy ounce in morning European trade, falling for the fourth session in a row.
US consumer confidence rose to 103.0 in September, up from 101.3 in August, which analysts say suggests financial market volatility in August hasn't unsettled consumers' upbeat outlook.
As a result, market attention will likely be on speeches being by members of the Fed Wednesday, "in the hope of receiving some indication of when the Fed might hike interest rates," said Commerzbank.
A rise in rates would strengthen the dollar, weakening dollar-denominated commodity. Gold also finds it easier to compete with interest-yielding assets, like Treasurys, when rates are pinned near zero.
Looking ahead, more US data and the dollar are likely to direct the precious metal.
"With NFPs [nonfarm payrolls] at the end of the week, I suspect we will stay range bound until then," says David Govett, head of precious metals trading at Marex Spectron, in a note.
Platinum prices rebounded slightly from near seven-year lows, meanwhile, after prices tested a low of $US900.46 an ounce in the previous session.
Spot platinum was trading up 1 per cent at $US923.11 an ounce.
Sentiment for the metal has grown increasingly bearish over the past fortnight as a result of the Volkswagen AG emissions scandal, which saw the German car maker admit 11 million of its diesel-engine vehicles were fitted with software to dodge strict US auto-pollution regulations. Some two million of these cars were sold in Europe -- the biggest diesel car market in the world.
Platinum is used twice as much as palladium in the autocatalysts of diesel engine cars, and fears that damage to the brand could see demand slump has led to a rush by investors to jettison some of their holdings.
Among the other precious metals, spot palladium continued to trade higher. It is almost exclusively used in gasoline engine vehicles, which could see an uptick in demand following the scandal.
Spot palladium was up 1.3 per cent at $US662.70 an ounce, and spot silver was up 0.4 per cent at $US14.665 an ounce.
